title: 114_hr1830
content: The "Water Rights Protection Act" defines a water right as any recognized surface or groundwater right. It includes rights for federally recognized Indian tribes. The Water Rights Protection Act prohibits the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture from conditioning permits on limitations or encumbrances of water rights granted under State law. The Water Rights Protection Act prohibits federal agencies from requiring water users to obtain water rights in the name of the United States as a condition for permits. It also limits federal jurisdiction over groundwater withdrawals and ensures that regulatory actions do not exceed state laws. The Water Rights Protection Act prohibits federal agencies from infringing on State rights in managing water resources originating on federal land. SEC. 4. RECOGNITION OF STATE AUTHORITY. In carrying out section 3, the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture must recognize State authority in evaluating, protecting, and regulating groundwater. They should coordinate with States to ensure Federal actions align with State groundwater laws and programs. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture must not take actions that harm State water rights, including definitions, groundwater regulations, and other State-established rights and obligations. The Act prohibits the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture from taking actions that could negatively impact State water rights. The Act does not limit or expand existing authority of the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture regarding permits, approvals, or land use agreements on Federal land. It also does not interfere with Bureau of Reclamation contracts or the Endangered Species Act. Additionally, it does not affect Federal reserved water rights on land administered by the Secretary.
